p: Fern et al. [ 127] reported that the leaves of P. betle are anthelmintic, antibacterial, antifungal, antiseptic, aphrodisiac, astringent, carminative, expectorant, laxative, sialagogue, stimulant, stomachic and tonic, and used to treat nosebleed, ulcerated noses, gums and mucous membranes while the leaf preparations and the leaf sap are applied to wounds, ulcers, boils and bruises. The leaf extract is applied for wounds in the ears and as an infusion for the eye while the leaf decoction is used to bathe a woman after childbirth, or is drunk to lessen an unpleasant body odor. Furthermore, the heated leaves of P. betle are applied as a poultice on the chest against cough and asthma, on the breasts to stop milk secretion, and on the abdomen to relieve constipation.
